description: E2Eオフライン検証用固定コーパス（ネットワーク不要）

papers.title: CD73 in tumor immunology and immunotherapy
papers.abstract: CD73 is an ecto-5'-nucleotidase that converts AMP to adenosine in the tumor microenvironment. High expression of CD73 on tumor cells and immunosuppressive cells contributes to immune evasion. CD73 inhibition enhances anti-tumor immunity by reducing adenosine levels and restoring T cell function. This review discusses CD73 as a therapeutic target for cancer immunotherapy.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.text: The tumor microenvironment (TME) is characterized by immunosuppressive features. CD73 (NT5E) is a key enzyme that generates extracellular adenosine from AMP.

sections.title: CD73 Expression
sections.text: CD73 is expressed on various cell types including tumor cells, regulatory T cells, and myeloid-derived suppressor cells. High CD73 expression correlates with poor prognosis in multiple cancer types.

sections.title: Therapeutic Strategies
sections.text: Monoclonal antibodies targeting CD73 (e.g., oleclumab) have shown promising results in clinical trials. Combination with PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitors may enhance efficacy.

papers.title: Adenosine pathway in cancer immunity
papers.abstract: The adenosine pathway, involving CD39 and CD73, plays a critical role in establishing an immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment. Therapeutic targeting of this pathway represents a promising strategy for cancer immunotherapy.

sections.title: Overview
sections.text: Adenosine is a potent immunosuppressive molecule. Its accumulation in tumors inhibits effector T cells and natural killer cells via A2A and A2B receptors.

sections.title: Mechanisms
sections.text: CD39 converts ATP to AMP, while CD73 converts AMP to adenosine. This two-step enzymatic process is enhanced in hypoxic tumor regions.

papers.title: CD73 inhibition for solid tumors
papers.abstract: CD73 inhibition represents a novel approach for treating solid tumors. Clinical trials have demonstrated safety and preliminary efficacy of CD73-targeting antibodies in combination with checkpoint inhibitors.

sections.title: Clinical Results
sections.text: Phase I/II trials of oleclumab combined with durvalumab showed objective responses in non-small cell lung cancer patients who had progressed on prior therapy.

papers.title: T cell exhaustion and adenosine signaling
papers.abstract: T cell exhaustion in tumors is partially mediated by adenosine signaling. Blocking the CD73-adenosine axis can restore T cell effector functions and enhance anti-tumor responses.

sections.title: T Cell Dysfunction
sections.text: Exhausted T cells exhibit reduced cytokine production, impaired proliferation, and increased expression of inhibitory receptors. Adenosine receptor signaling exacerbates these features.

papers.title: Biomarkers for CD73-targeted therapy
papers.abstract: Identifying predictive biomarkers for CD73-targeted therapy is essential for patient selection. CD73 expression, adenosine levels, and TME composition may serve as potential biomarkers.

sections.title: Biomarker Candidates
sections.text: Tumor CD73 expression by immunohistochemistry has been correlated with response to CD73 inhibitors in early clinical trials.
